title: How to Make Sauerkraut Juice

steps.headline: Peel off the outer leaves of the cabbage.
steps.description: You should remove any leaves that are discolored or wilted.

steps.headline: Feed the cabbage wedges through a juicer with a mincing screen.
steps.description: If you don’t have a juicer, you can shred the cabbage in a food processor or grate it by hand.

steps.headline: Put the shredded cabbage into a medium sized bowl.
Add the salt and the apple juice and mix well.
Press the mixture into a 1 pint (.473 L) Mason jar or other glass container that has a tight fitting lid.
steps.description: Fill the jar to just under the rim with the shredded cabbage.

steps.headline: Use a spoon to press the cabbage down into the jar so that there are no air pockets.
steps.description: Add more cabbage, if needed, to fill the jar almost to the top.

steps.headline: Add water to bring the mixture up to the brim of the jar.
steps.description: You want to leave just enough room to be able to screw on the lid.

steps.headline: Screw the lid onto the jar.
steps.description: Make sure it is screwed on tightly; you may have to remove bits of cabbage from the jar’s threads in order to get a tight fit—simply run a clean, wet cloth around the threads.

steps.headline: Set the jar in a bowl.
steps.description: The cabbage will start fermenting and flow down the sides of the jar, so keeping the jar in a bowl will keep your countertop clean.

steps.headline: Let the juice ferment for 5 or 6 days.
Unscrew the lid and pour the sauerkraut juice into a glass.
steps.description: It’s best to drink it all right away, but if you can’t, cover any remaining juice and refrigerate it.
